Pours a hazed golden copper with a dense fluffy white head. Nose has heavy with resiny tropical fruits and earthy pine. Flavor is a little sweeter, with grapefruit rind, pineapple, mango and peach and a dry earthy pine and grassy finish. Medium thick body, soft carbonation and a sticky, bitter finish. Great balance of hops as the Simcoe pine plays nicely with the leafy NZ hop tropical fruitiness. The Riwaka single hop was a little more "exceptional" and a better showcase for that hop, but Susans subtlety and balance make this much easier to drink.

The smell and overall scores are more of a 4.75 but I refuse to use the new quarter intervals in scores since I never had access to them the previous 6 years of reviewing. Just...whatever.

Pours a hazy pale orange with a creamy medium white head...nice lacing.  Aroma is dominated with stonefruits...sweet peach nectar!  Flavor follows suit and adds a layer of spicy/earthy bitterness...very tasty.  Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is earthy/bitter...very bitter...dry.

Growler shared....Hazy bright yellow pour,two finger soapy white head.Good lacing.Aroma of grapefruit,lemon and some tropical/melon notes.Faint malt sweetness,firm bitterness.Notes of orange,pine and grapefruit.I also get some green onion ,but Im the only one getting that. Light on the palate but bitter enough.Drinks with ease,smooth and well balanced.

From a 750ml "bomber" pour. Cloudy light orange. Aroma is passionfruit, orange, grapefruit. Slightly sticky mouthfeel, well balanced on the palate, fruity citrus finish. Taste is passionfruit, sweet orange. Very nice - best IPA Ive ever encountered.

750ml growler courtesy of a great BA trader. the pour is an incredibly bright but hazy peach color capped by a fluffy, rocky white head that leaves dense sheets of lace. aroma is incredible, one of the best ive ever experienced, with massive, tropical, citra hop notes of pineapple, tangerine, apricot, and mango backed by white grapefruit, dense pine, and lime peels with subtle hints of honey covered biscuits and vanilla as it opens up, flavor is damn near perfect as well with a blast of juicy tangerines, grapefruit, and nectarines up front with sweet pineapple, papaya, and stonefruit through the middle before finishing with rush of resinous pine, herbal bitterness, and wet grass. palate is immensely drinkable with a light body and perfect carbonation and that combination of juicy citrus and resiny bitterness that i love. overall, a truly world class ipa and perhaps the best ive had from HF.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2012 Growler thanks to Alec Bull.  Pours light orange and SUPER hazy.  Nose is fruity, citrus, dank resin, pines, and more tropical fruits with a light nose of sweeter malts mixed in.  Flavor is bright grapefruits, tropical fruits, grass, resins, pines, peaches, sweet malts to start then dries out nicely and leaves a very lightly toasted malt quality lingering. Good beer. medium body and definitely not lacking in carbonation.  Glad to have another good offering from them
Pour a beautiful orange with a finger white head. Citrus and fresh grass in the nose.  Bitter to slight sweetness. Dry.  Well balanced. Nice beer.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2013 Oh my my! So good you know good just like the other good Vermont beers that have good hop flavors. I feel bad for those other bad boys that didnt get to try this one with me an my pals. Mouthfeel, aroma, flavors, taste, appearance is all very perfect. Unique and enjoyable so yum. bread, cereal, hay, resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, dough, ginger, , grass, grass, grass, grass, grass,

Bottle share by Ryan, big time pineapple and pine scents. Taste is some nice sweet and pine, a bit of citrus, killer IPA.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

December 15, 2012 bottle/growler via trade with Reynolds314.  Pour was a cloudy neon yellow with nice head and lacing.  Hoppy aroma with some fruitiness, citrus orange and acidic lemon.  This was nicely balanced and finished clean.  A very well done IPA, wow amazing.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle - thanks Folty! Bright neon yellow pour with a white head. Very citrusy and sweet - Darcy Folty says peach, Daddy Folty says lemon - both are correct. Excellent brew.
Nice growler pour.  Yellowish in color with a nice white head.  Very smooth and well balanced.  Refreshing.  Light citrus.

Poured from a growler shared graciously at a bottle share. Pours a lighter gold with a white head of foam. The aroma is really fresh, earthy, citrusy hops. Taste is bitter and sweet like an orange peel. Nice.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2012 Cloudy typical hill farmstead ipa appearance. Big soapy head.Aroma is sweet, hop pellets, definitely citra in the aroma. Sweet flavor it seems a bit green like the pulled it off before it was done huge residual sweetness like unfernmented wort. Citra dominant. Medium to low bitterness. Nice.

Holy intense aroma! The nose on this is redonk! Immense blast of grapefruit, citrus, mango and pine. This is a fruity, yet dank IPA! The malt balance is also exceptional and even apparent on the nose. Im thinking there may be some malted rye in this, as I get almost a spicy/rustic malt presence from the aroma. Appearance is a murky copper color with a nice white creamy head. Taste is spot on - grapefruit, tropical fruits, citrus, pine and dank marijuana-like herbals. This also has a great mouthfeel - perfect carbonation for the style yet full bodied. This is extremely well balanced and it shows. This might be one of my favorite IPAs to date.

Draft at WLV for Zwanze Day 2012. Pours very attractive, deep orange-gold with a sticky white head. Nose is big on hops but somewhat generic. Lacks the pop youd expect from the hops chosen. Grapefruit and resin, faint tropical note. Stiff malt component as well. On tasting, faint sweetness, firm bitterness overall. Hop flavor sticks with citrus and a hint of marmalade. Dry finish. Very well crafted IPA but lacks something to make it pop. Id drink a ton of this if it were available but its not in my top 10...

Sampled at Zwanze Day - 2012 (Chicago, IL). Pours a richly hazy pour, darker golden amber pour, richer haze, mellow deep dark murky glow on the edges. Frothy offwhite head laces well atop, firm layer overall. Lingers. Aromas are rich grapefruit, lemon, and florals. Rich hop aroma as it settles, some melon and kisses of tropical fruit. Rich hop presence is intoxicating. Initial is lighter end of the fold with firm bitterness, bigger grapefruit and floral elements. Some grass, kiss of pine. Gentle melon and tropical fruit. Bready malts, grains. Middle is richly bitter, big citrus and bitter resiny elements. Backend shows dryness, grapefruit, florals. Some bread, grain, richly bitter elements jump in and out. Finish is lingering trailing florals, resin, and citrus. Light and airy at times, richly hoppy. Solid fresh hop offering. I wouldnt call it the most complex one, but its very good.

Growler. Pours a deep golden hazy orange with medium white head. Aroma is pineapple, grapefruit and some hop. Taste is a very well balanced, grapefruit bitterness at the front, no real sweetness, more tropical fruits and finishes extremely dry.  A very well crafted single IPA that showcase the simcoe and citra.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Pour from a growler at home gave a characteristic HF color of murky gold orange. Aromas of fruit, flowers,  and yeast. Flavors are exceptionally luscious with the tropical pineapple, mango of the Citra and Riwaka, and the characteristic Simcoe floral citrus. Just moderately bitter and fairly dry finish. Long retention of flavors on your palate. Really great beer.

On tap at the Prohibition Pig in Waterbury.  Hazy golden yellow body, moderate white head, decent lacing.  Nose is a blend of mild grapefruit, pine, and orange.  Pleasant, but not particularly aromatic.  Flavor is similar in complexion, but the beers mild character plays better on the tongue.  Medium bodied, appropriately carbonated, refreshing bitter finish.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2012 Had on tap at the source. Pours a mildewed light orange with a trim soapy whitish head. Smells of clementine zest, sesame, chamomile flowers and yeast. Tastes wonderfully of white grapefruit, American hops, citrus and a growing pleasurable heat. Yummy, for sure.

Enjoyed on tap at Zwanze Day, 2012. Served in a my Zwanze taster.

A: Pours a cloudy apricot color with a frothy off white head forming on the pour. It recedes slowly to a thick ring and leaves some soapy lace down the glass.

S: Very fruit forward nose. Very intoxicating mix of peach, pineapple, apricot and stone fruit. slightly grassy with a sweet biscuit malt backbone. 

T: The malt base is a little heavier in the taste. Biscuit and toffee with sweet bursts of pineapple and peach.

M: Medium to light bodied with a nice medium-high carbonation level. Fruity and sweet flavors left on the palate.

O: High drinkable with a great fruit forward nose and taste. Definitely enjoyed this one!

Serving type: on-tap

On draft as part of Zwanze 2012 at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago.   Pour was a hazy yellow with small head.  Nose was a hoppy celebration of pine and fruity mango...taste was very similar...burst in my mouth.  I may have to move to Vermont!  Wonderful / tasty!

On draft at West Lakeview for Zwanze Day 2012.  Reviewed from memory. Pours a cloudy amber color with a white head.  Aroma is hoppy, pine, mango, grapefruit.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, light bready malt, and a ton of hops, pine mango, pineapple, grapefruit.  An excellent IPA.
Draft, hazy gold with head. Aroma has peach, pine needles, grapefruit rind. Flavors are piney, grapefruit rind, lemon. Really dry and piney finish.

On tap for VSK. Aroma like WHOA! Smells like I stuck my head inside a grapefruit. Hoppy and fantastic. Taste has too much hop resin and bite for my preference. If you like single IPAs you'll prob enjoy it more than I did.

750mL growler, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks a lot, Dany!), pours a cloudy, completely opaque, dulled orange with a medium white head. Aromatics are incredibly orgasmic, like all Hill Farmstead hoppy beers, with loads of orange peels, mangos, peaches, truckloads of resinous hops and a big caramel malt backbone. Flavour brings out loads of tropical fruits (mangos, peaches and pineapple), juicy mandarin oranges, bitter grapefruit, and truckloads of resinous hops. Flavours are incredibly rich and deep somehow for only being 6.2% (I would guess this was more like 9% due to the flavour depth, not because of any boozy quality). Finishes quite bitter, on the grapefruity notes. Extremely refreshing and again, immensely flavourful. Must be the best non-Imperial IPA Ive had. Most amazing.

Growlerette filled at the source two days ago.
Pours a cloudy murky light yellow golden color with a decent sized bone white head that slowly fades to a smattering of lace. That aroma is intoxicating, literally! Wiked old school citrus of grapefruit, orange, and lemon with pine with hints of resin. If theres malt in there I cant smell it, but shit I dont miss it, Ive got a hop chubby. The flavor does hold some light bready malt but the citrus hop flavor is the dominatrix to my taste buds. Grapefruit, tropical fruits, tangerines, pine, resin its all there and it all melds together wonderfully. Smooth never harsh bitterness provides balance to the little malt I can find. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a smooth resinous mouthfeel. It doesnt look like much in the glass, but thats a damn fine beer right there.

Growler poured into my bubble glass.  Hazy Orange with a nice white head which dissipated quickly.  Smell of pine, hops and citrus peel.  Taste follows through on the smell, grapefruit pith vs juice like society 5.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2012 Growler poured into tulip glass.  Golden straw color with medium white head.  Aroma is grapefruit rind, doughy malts, light grass, and citrus zest.  Taste is very heavy grapefruit with light touch of sweetness and a nice drisp dry bitterness on the finish.  Great IPA.  One of the best regular IPAs ever.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2012 Growler at home with my dad, courtesy of Adam. Big thanks for this one man!! Pour is hazy, honeycomb in appearance with a big white head and great lacing. Huge grapefruit, mango, a touch of pine, grass, orange peel, and tangerines in the aroma. Like a glass full of sweet, fresh-squeezed fruit juice. Taste is sweet pineapples, mango, grapefruit peel, orange juice, resin, tangerines, and papaya with a big bitter finish. Medium mouthfeel with high carbonation. Super tropical and one of the fruitiest IPAs I have ever tasted with huge bitterness; literally tastes like a glass full of freshly squeezed grapefruit juice. Awesome!

2L growler poured into HF stemware. Pours a opaque orange with a two finger head... pretty much resembles other HF hoppy beers.

Grapefruit and green peppers seem to be at the forefront, followed by orange, lemon and a little bit of hay... farmy. Smells fantastic. Taste follows, grapefruit seeming to be the highlight. Very mild bitterness, and a dry finish.

A great IPA that I am honored to have in my glass. Big thanks to my beer homies for giving me a chance to try this.

Growler sample via and shared with oakbluff. Murky pale orange in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of tangerine, papaya, hop sack, and a touch of pale malt. Great flavors of juicy whte grapefruit, mandarin orange, and weeds, balanced out by just enough crispy pale malts. Sharp clean bitterness, and refreshingly light bodied. A world class IPA.

Flip top bottle from chouffe.  Hazy dark gold color with a thick fluffy off-white head.  Plenty clings to the glass after each sip.  The aroma definitely showcases a tropical fruit theme; grapefruit, pineapple, tangerine, and lemon zest.  Some herbal character mingles in with light biscuity notes.  Not unexpected, theres lots of tropical fruit, citrus rind, and earthy hop flavors.  But theres also some assertive pine towards the back end.  The finish is mostly dry with crisp bitterness and just a little lingering sticky sweetness.  The body is sturdy, perhaps a shade heavier than expected, but slick and easy going down.  Although Id say this drinks a tick stronger than it really is.  The Society & Solitude #5 I had the other day is better than this one but this could definitely be a sibling to it.  Another very fine IPA from Hill Farmstead.

Growler that Dany picked up for me because he is a wonderful person.  Enjoyed this in my hotel room paired up with a falafel.  Really doesnt get much better than that.  Pours a rather hazy golden amber with a medium sized white head.  Big succulent citrus and hops on the nose, dripping with resinous hops, beautiful.  Medium bodied, big bold citrus and pungent earthy grapefruit comes through right away.  Picks up a bit of sweetness and a bit of warming alcohol.  Long spicy and pithy grapefruit and a long lengthy bitterness with some warming alcohol on the finish.  Another amazing IPA from Shaun and company.
On draft at brewery, very drinkable and a great blend of the hops. Im glad Sheryl came.

Draft at Farmhouse in Burlington- thanks to Jeff for having this one on tap for my visit! Pours a lovely hazy orange with that classic dense, gorgeous frothy white Hill Farmstead head. Nose brings a stunning initial hit of grapefruit rind, both more bitter white zest character with sweeter pink flesh flavor, along with tangerine, clementine, apricot, honeydew, and assertive pine. The flavor continues to bring wave after wave of immensely flavorful citrus backed by subtle but beautifully bittering evergreen and balancing nectar fruit sweetness. The mouthfeel is just full enough, but beautifully drinkable with a lasting bitterness that almost seems to provide a 5 second respite causing the facade of a smooth finish, then attacking you again for that lingering hop bite. An absolutely stunning lower alcohol IPA; could be my favorite.
750 flip top growler thanks to Scott. Big tropical fruit nose. Amazing aroma. Bitterness met with more tropical flavors. Pineapple. Grapefruit. Lots of citrus. Another fantastic beer from HF.

750ml from brewery. Pours a hazy light orange golden color with a finger of fluffy foam. Aromas are big citrus and stonefruit; nectarine, peach, tangerine and pineapple. Amazing mouthfeel and a light juicy carbonation that delivers the complex flavors perfectly. Touches of pine and lime sneak through mid to late palate when a big grapefruit bitterness comes to dry it all out and start all over again.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2012 Draft at Blind Tiger with whole slew of dads. Pours a deep, hazy orange body with light white lacing, pretty much no head. Aroma is fresh dank citrus, light pine, pineapple, and citric hop. Mouthfeel is medium and smooth with notes of tropical fruits, grapefruit, pineapple, light funk, creamy butter, light malt balance and pine hops. Very drinkable - probably could have sessioned on this all day if it hadnt kicked in 30 minutes. Beautiful beer.

On tap at Blind Tiger.  Kicked in about 25-30 minutes.  A damn fine IPA.  Has Heady like qualities with regard to aroma and taste.  Obviously lighter on mouthfeel.  Pours a pale hazy orange color with fluffy white head.  Aroma is just wonderful.  Grapefruit forward.  Like diving into an orchard.  Has a heavier feel for straight IPA.  Hop hit is more earthy than malted so not super smooth but in a good way for hop lovers.  Vermont makes great IPAs.  Cant wait for my next one.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2012 On tap with James and a small crew at blind tiger, hazy almost murky orange-gold pour. So much grapefruit citrus, tropical pineapple, butter, caramel, and cheese, pine and lots of tropical notes. Awesome mouthfeel, so sweet and refreshing with a nice hop bitter finish at the end. Highlight of the event for me. If it was a little more dry and citrus dominant it would have been epic. Maybe a little too much sugar left behind but still world class. Tried again via growler at Franks, enjoyed this version better then the one at B Tiger. More dryness and more new zealend cheese, thit yoo, thats some thitt

On tap at the Brewery. The pour is mega hazy straw with a perfect creamy head that lasts throughout the glass. The aroma holds explosive citrus and nectar fruit- think tangerine, mandarin orange, and apricot with an assertive background of orange peel and clementine. Hints of green pepper that I also got from the Riwaka single hop and Cantillon Mamouche- not unpleasant whatsoever, and super interesting. The flavor bursts with orange and juicy nectar fruit, leaving hints of pine, and finishing with a very strong grapefruit juice character. The palate is quenching and bone dry in the finish with fluffy meringue like carbonation that provokes an immediate and viscerally compulsory followup gulp. A near perfect ipa for my tastes...

Tap.  Aroma is focused on citrus hops, bold mango and grapefruit jump out of the glass, some pine and resin.  Nice malt in the nose as well, bread, some toast, and notes of honey.  Pours hazy golden, thick white head has good retention and laces nicely.  Flavor is a fantastic balance of hops and malt.  Big burst of hops, lots dank grapefruit and tropical fruit, bitterness is high up front but integrates nicely as the malt flavors come in.  Honey and biscuit malt meld well with the hop charge.  Medium body and carbonation, smooth and drinkable.  Excellent.

On tap at Hill Farmstead Brewery and again out of a 750ML Growler in an HFS tulip at around 50 Degrees F. 

A - Bright and cloudy. Unfiltered and full of gorgeous complexity as a super intense orange color. 3 Fingers of fluffy white head that seems to never go away at least over 5 minutes. Very resilient lacing on the swish and subsequent fiddling with the glass. 

S - Citra hops dominate the nose. Huge grapefruit, tangerine and lime scents. Its a citrus bomb with a hint of pine in the back of my throat. 

T - Huge hop bitterness strikes first. Like Abner or Society 3, the huge citrus notes fill the mouth aided by a big and generous carbonation that is 2nd only to soda in the way the bubbles tingle and fill your mouth and keep on tingling. Huge level of fresh whole oranges juiced into a glass ice cold and refreshing. There is a chewy hop bitterness of pine needles and grapefruit with pineapple. 

M - Medium body but a mouth drying carbonation. Its not high carbonation but its how the carbonation interacts with the flavors to make the beer better. Susan on cask would simply not be the same. The small level of CO2 makes this beer so much better. Everything is accentuated. 

O - This is an exceptionally well balanced beer for being so bitter. Every last drop was perfect. i was the first person on RB to review Society & Solitude #5. I gave that beer a 4.8 and, having both of these beers side by side tonight, I stand by that SC5 review. This beer is NOT the same as SC5 but its still delicious and drinkable. I wont give it a 4.8 but its damn close. Great job, Shaun!
